discourse_list.title: Endgame: Different starting point for DVCs

content.content: Hi endgamers & community, as we look at grouping delegates/reconfiguring how MKR holders go about delegation, I want to question the hawk–dove prototype for DVCs. Two groups in a governing system are codependent on each other. One group is forced to be reactionary against the other, and vice versa. It creates a spiral that necessarily divides communities. American government is the really obvious example of this. A much healthier prototype for this kind of governance would have three DVCs as a basis. This way the groups aren’t constantly defining themselves in opposition to each other. I’m curious what people might think of as far as three sets of values to group delegates around, but what I’ve been mulling over is forming DVCs around different end states for the currencies. “DAI Everywhere DVC”, “Bank Yourself DVC”, and “Tokenized Bond Pioneer DVC” could be a triad of committees that each has its own identity but removes the reactionary element of a two-party system, as an example. I know the goal is to ultimately have more than two DVCs, but if we prototype the system as having two parties, it will begin a process of reactionary interplay that could also simply be avoided. Thanks for reading!

content.content: This is a great idea, and I think the basic logic that one more “launch DVC” doesn’t cause much additional complexity and solves a lot of risks or at least perceived risks related to having just two major DVCs. I had already been developing a third DVC strategy that I think fills a natural gap, so I can just accelerate that and “launch” it asap, which requires relatively little work.

content.content: On the other hand, if the goal is to create governance that is very difficult to change without widespread consensus, the US government is a great model to look at. Making any significant change at the federal level is very difficult and mostly happens in extreme circumstances.

content.content: I think the point you make regarding the two-sided system of delegate committees does lend-itself to a system that will be very “hawks vs. doves” mentality as you mentioned. It is puts people in a situation of making a purely binary choice of having to allow progress or hitting a “stop-everything” button for a lot of different moving parts. Having parties aligned to broader end-states than tied to one-specific game-plan or another will make it easier for delegates to assign themselves along principles rather than just an ideological yes/no vote on a current system. The power of these committees is determined by the current MKR-token holder views anyway (if everyone is super pro-endgame, then great, that party will denominate) but having more parties than just two gives people the opportunity to hedge their vote for-and-against certain policies as they are implemented (their are quiet a lot of stages to the endgame plan!) without opposing an entire roadmap.
